specs/victoria/approved/cinder-ceph-repl.message: It took me a long time to understand why. It is because you want to replicate only ceph images owned by cinder but not the other images, correct? Please explain in this document, thanks!

Yes, exactly. I will try to clarify in the spec as well.

There's only a minor difference between the `pool` and `image` mirroring modes: when `image` mirroring mode is used, each Ceph image must be explicitly enabled for mirroring. This is an extra flag for each Ceph image. And when `pool` mode is used, all the images will have mirroring enabled by default, and you don't need to explicitly enable it.

Keep in mind that the `exclusive-lock` and `journaling` image features are required for the mirroring to work, regardless of the mirroring mode used.

Now, coming back to the Cinder context. The Ceph RBD driver will:
* take care of setting the required image features for mirroring (`exclusive-lock` and `journaling`). And that's why we don't need to set these features by default via the client ceph.conf (as it is happening at the moment), since Cinder takes care of it.
* explicitly enable image mirroring. And that's why we need `image` mirroring mode.

Actual driver implementation on this at: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/stable/ussuri/cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py#L777-L785.

I found only some general official OpenStack documentation on Cinder replication at: https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/ussuri/contributor/replication.html. Unfortunately, this only a driver-agnostic documentation, and it doesn't point to any driver implementation.

These are some other good sources that helped me clarify the Cinder Ceph replication:
* https://ceph.io/planet/openstack-cinder-configure-replication-api-with-ceph/
* http://www.sebastien-han.fr/blog/2016/03/28/ceph-jewel-preview-ceph-rbd-mirroring/
* https://gist.github.com/jbernard/1d7359cac7641216659066b3860760d6
should be rbd-mirroring-mode instead of rbd_mirroring_mode
Yep. That's the format for the charm config options. I will update this.

The phrasing here is a bit strange because:
1. it feels like you're talking about sending flags to clients
2. it feels like the client is asking for a mirroring mode.

I think what you truly mean is: On top of this, the ceph-mon charm should not send the RBD mirroring flags to the ceph-rbd-mirror charm for images coming from non-cinder clients. We can safely assume that those clients would explicitly set those flags if they were interested in replication.

Quick update on this one:

I noticed that ceph-mon sends the default RBD features into the entire `ceph-client` relation.

Filtering out the `journaling` feature from the default RBD features into the ceph-mon charm, based on which application units requested the `image` mirroring mode, is not cleanly implemented (and it's not efficient either).

I think it's easier to implement this logic into the Ceph client through an extra update to the charm-helpers.

At the moment, any Ceph client will look for the `rbd-features` relation variable and use that as the default RBD features into the client ceph.conf:
* https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/blob/v0.20.18/charmhelpers/contrib/openstack/context.py#L797-L800
* https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/blob/v0.20.18/charmhelpers/contrib/openstack/templates/ceph.conf#L15-L17 

For the extra charm-helpers update, I'm thinking about this: https://github.com/ionutbalutoiu/charm-cinder-ceph/commit/53f47fe1419708e74a29da537756e5adad07ad2c.

Basically, don't use any explicit default RBD features if the Ceph client charm (for example cinder-ceph) implements the new config option `rbd-mirror-mode`, and it's set to `image`. We will rely on the default features provided by Ceph, and Cinder will explicitly enable needed features for mirroring.

What do you think about this idea ?
https://github.com/ionutbalutoiu/charm-cinder-ceph/commit/53f47fe1419708e74a29da537756e5adad07ad2c makes sense to me, thanks!

To directly respond:
1. Yes, the `ceph-mon` charm sends rbd features to the clients (which are going to be used by default for all the images).
2. Yes, the clients could ask for mirroring mode (that's why we have the extra config option with `rbd-mirroring-mode`) as part of the broker request to create a pool. This will be optional, and if clients didn't set it, and we have RBD mirroring, it will just do the previous `pool` mirroring mode (thus we maintain backwards compatibility).

This paragraph talks about `ceph-client` interface implementation between the `ceph-mon` and `cinder-ceph` (or any other clients).

At the moment, we the following workflow:
* `cinder-ceph` sets the necessary broker request to create the Ceph pool.
* `ceph-mon` handles the broker request, and sets the response back to the `cinder-ceph`, and it also sets an additional `rbd-features` variable (https://github.com/openstack/charm-ceph-mon/blob/stable/20.08/hooks/ceph_hooks.py#L201-L203) that will go into `ceph.conf` used by the Ceph client (https://github.com/openstack/charm-cinder-ceph/blob/stable/20.08/charmhelpers/contrib/openstack/templates/ceph.conf#L15-L17).

However, when `ceph-mon` has a relation with `ceph-rbd-mirror`, it will append the rbd mirroring features (`exclusive-lock` and `journaling`) to the default rbd features used for all the Ceph images by `cinder-ceph`:
* https://github.com/openstack/charm-ceph-mon/blob/stable/20.08/hooks/utils.py#L264-L265
* https://github.com/openstack/charm-ceph-mon/blob/stable/20.08/hooks/utils.py#L242-L252

So, the final client `ceph.conf` for the `cinder-ceph` charm will have `rbd default features` with mirroring features appended there. Which means that every Cinder Ceph image will have `journaling` and `exclusive-lock` enabled.

However, this is orchestrated by Cinder, and only images with replication enabled will get these flags explicitly set.

My idea is to have `ceph-mon` check if the `cinder-ceph` (or any Ceph clients) set the mirroring to `image` as part of the broker request. If that is true, don't advertise the RBD mirroring flags to the clients, since this will be handled by them.

here also I think this isn't exactly what you mean. What you mean is, I think: When sending the RBD features to the ceph-rbd-mirror charm, do not blindly append the RBD mirroring features for images coming from non-cinder clients.
I explained above what it means. The mirroring features are set by the ceph-mon, if the relation with ceph-rbd-mirror is present.
what will be the name of this relation?
Oh, I forgot about the relation name. I would name it `mirror-pool-access`.
This is confusing me because I thought we were doing here per-image mirroring and now we're talking about checking that a whole pool is mirrored?

I was talking about checking if the pool is mirrored (aka: has mirroring enabled), regardless of the mirroring mode used.

So, Cinder needs access to the remote cluster (where images are mirrored) to promote those images as primary and use them going forward, when a failover happens. This is given in `cinder.conf` as the `replication_device` config. See an example here: https://gist.github.com/jbernard/1d7359cac7641216659066b3860760d6#cinder-configuration.

The ceph-rbd-mirror charm is capable of giving its connection details to the remote cluster (since he has access to it), and it can validate that the pool has mirroring enabled. I believe that `cinder-ceph` will not have any use of the remote cluster info if the mirroring is not properly set.
Do you have a link to that code in charm-helpers? Because I'm not sure what you're talking about

Sure. This is the code that needs to ultimately go into the charm-helpers: https://github.com/ionutbalutoiu/charm-helpers/commit/376d9a4e8a4591153260ee38cdad903402dd498b

It basically adds a new flag to the `create-pool` op request that the `cinder-ceph` (or any other Ceph clients) send to `ceph-mon`. The same request is going to be forwarded to the `ceph-rbd-mirror` charm, which will handle it.

Keep in mind that this based on the logic to forward the broker request into some recent patches from Frode:
* https://review.opendev.org/#/c/756885/
* https://review.opendev.org/#/c/755781/

The plan is to implement the spec on top of those patches, because it allows a cleaner implementation of the new `rbd-mirror-mode` flag.
What about https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/charm-deployment-guide/latest/app-ceph-rbd-mirror.html ?

I took a look at the document. It assumes that the mirroring mode is set to `pool` and all the Ceph images have the mirroring features (`journaling` and `exclusive-lock`). And the promote / demote of primary images is done via the Juju actions.

In the context of Cinder Ceph replication with `image` mirror mode, Ceph Ceph RBD driver takes care of this. I believe that we should at least have an additional `NOTE` in the document stating that the Juju actions to manually promote / demote all the images shouldn't be used if the pool RBD mirror is set to `image` (assuming that the actual client, for example Cinder, is responsible to do this).

However, I noticed an interesting note in the document:
"RBD mirroring makes use of the journaling feature of Ceph. This incurs an overhead for write activity on an RBD image that will adversely affect performance."

This is a validation to the approach described above to not append the rbd mirroring features (`journaling` and `exclusive-lock`) to the default rbd features when `image` mirror mode is enabled. And let Cinder append these Ceph image features, if replication is enabled on a particular volume.

I think it's good to mention here why you wouldn't want to just use the 'pool' mode and have all ceph images mirrored. The reason is that you only want to mirror the ceph images coming from cinder, so you don't want to blindly mirror all ceph images.
Good point. I'll update here.
Good to mention why it needs these credentials: it's for being able to perform a failover.
I will add this mention as well.
why does it need to be a new relation? why not passing that info through the existing ceph-client relation?

The cinder-ceph charm has an existing relation with the ceph-mon, but that's meant to be used to configure the Ceph backend to the local Ceph cluster.

In the context of mirroring, we have another remote Ceph cluster (where images are mirrored). And cinder-ceph needs access to that as well, to start using it after a failover.

So, the second implementation of the ceph-client interface is meant to be used only to relate with the remote ceph-mon charm from the other site. And it adds the `replication_device` config into `cinder.conf`:
https://gist.github.com/jbernard/1d7359cac7641216659066b3860760d6#cinder-configuration

We're doing something similar with the ceph-rbd-mirror charm, where we implement the same interface twice: https://github.com/openstack/charm-ceph-rbd-mirror/blob/stable/20.08/src/metadata.yaml#L32-L35.

One relation is meant to be used with the local Ceph cluster, and the other one with the remote Ceph cluster.

That's exactly the same approach that I did here with cinder-ceph. Since Cinder requires access to local & remote cluster when Cinder replication mechanism is enabled.

If looking at the code helps, this is the implementation of it: https://github.com/ionutbalutoiu/charm-cinder-ceph/commit/0cc2e1c4a02c1ba1bbbb614429cfebeabb37f137.

requires.py.message:
Perhaps I'm missing something but I think this function is badly named. Its primary function seems to be to broadcast the request down all relations, shouldn't send_request_if_needed look after making sure that a duplicate request isn't sent?
If I'm missing the point then I think the doc string needs expanding on.

Looking at the c-h code here it does appear that I'm having a redundant check here indeed. I'll remove and reconfirm operation.

There is typically only one charm in the other end of this relation, the ceph-mon, I'll expand on the documentation too.

I included this patch in the implementation work for the Cinder Ceph replication spec, and I have some feedback.

I don't think that we need to yield JSON object here. I believe that we need to yield `ch_ceph.CephBrokerRq(raw_request_data=json_rq)`.

I patched the `ceph-rbd-mirror` interface with the update from here, and I also updated the `ceph-rbd-mirror` charm handlers to properly forward the broker request to the remote Ceph via the above `maybe_send_rq` method: https://github.com/ionutbalutoiu/charm-ceph-rbd-mirror/commit/b2de2f6eb0d36db28be20b37957c495ccda42a68#diff-5d6afa6e630f1f38257166003cc63cbb2e2dff926e6e1887eccea5111e4daafcR101. 

If we yield JSON object, I'm getting the error: https://paste.ubuntu.com/p/qdmBCdQcBq.

This happens, because `ch_ceph.send_request_if_needed(rq, relation=self.endpoint_name)` from above expects a `CephBrokerRq` parameter, and we'll be sending a JSON object.

If we yield `CephBrokerRq` objects here instead of simple JSON objects, everything is fine.

The interface change was authored in combination with these changes to the ceph-rbd-mirror charm:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/755782/10/src/reactive/ceph_rbd_mirror_handlers.py
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/755782/10/src/lib/charm/openstack/ceph_rbd_mirror.py

The list of Dicts are filtered and turned into CephBrokerRq's in the charm code there.

I guess we could do it in the interface too, but it feels a bit wasteful as the charm has to process them before it can be sent on the wire anyway. A charm relation always holed one single CephBrokerRq with multiple ops in it.

This detail definitively should be more clear in the interface code whichever way we choose to roll.

I believe your approach is better. We will also need to process the BrokerReqs for the Cinder Ceph replication spec implementation.

I'll be working on top of your above patch then. Thank-you!

After adding sriov capabilities and restart of compute node, the PCIDevTracker updates the stats pools based on information available in DB (dev_type for the device is type-PCI at this point). The hypervisor resource update gets triggered which corrects the DB (changes dev_type to type-PF) but the stats pools are not updated based on changes in dev_type.

In short, the DB gets corrected after restart of compute node but not the PCI stats pools. The only way to verify is to assert the stats object directly using self.compute.manager.rt.pci_tracker.stats
Is this a good way to use the stats object directly for assertions given these are functional tests? Could you please suggest.

this shoudl never happen at runtime but it can happen if you do a firmware update or in some case reconfigure a device form datacenter bridning mode to sriov mode.

basically this will only happen if a device previously did not support sriov virtual fucntions but then gain the ablity to support virtual function in the pci config space capablities.

so this is an exceeing rare edgecase but it can happen with devices like intel QAT if they are running a very very old firmware and kernel

other device might also cahnge in this way.

a better example is PF passthough 

if you allocate the VF at runtime then do a PF pasthough when you detach the PF from the vm the VF wont be reallocated in which case we end up with a bunch of VF in the DB that nolonger exist on the host.

ill pull donw this patch on monday and see if it also fixes that case if not we might want to exted it to also cover that case. i was going to file a bug for it after i noticed it yesterday but it would be nice to cover both cases in one patch so we can backport it together.

there is a third use case that this might fix that i became aware of last week realted to changeing the numa toplody fo the host via a bios change.

i belive that this patch as written should correct that use cause but it would be nice ot have functional test to validate that too.

This naming logic is a duplicate of what happens in the Server class constructor below. Instead of duplication, can we refactor this out as a static method in the Server class and then call it from here?

E.g:

  @staticmethod
  def sanitize_server_name(servername):
      if '-' not in servername:
          servername = '%s-server' % servername
      cmd = 'swift-%s' % servername
      return servername, cmd

Then in here in Manager.verify_server:

  server, cmd = Server.sanitze_server_name(server)

And in the constructor of Server:

  self.server, self.cmd = self.sanitize_server_name(self.server) 

NOTE: you can pick a better name

security/swtpm/centos/swtpm.spec.message:
what user or group is 'tss' ?
should group be 'root' as well ?

From what I am reading "tss" user would be required with swtpm_setup for TPM 1.2 because it depends on TrouSerS's tcsd. TrouSerS is an implementation of the Trusted Computing Group's Software Stack (TSS) specification. 
In article https://github.com/stefanberger/swtpm/issues/37, I read that there are options: " One can pass --with-tss-user=<user name> and --with-tss-group=<group name> to the swtpm configure script to select a different user than 'tss' if that user doesn't exist on the system. 'root' can also be chosen." 
The openscap requirement to pass the scap rule "Verify that System Executables Have Root Ownership" was to just change the user ownership to be root. After the change the rule passed.

It looks like "tss" gets created by the tpm2-abrmd RPM. It might be a good idea to add an explicit "Requires: tpm2-abrmd" to the tools package around line 98 to ensure the group exists at the time this package is installed.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I think something like this would be more accurate:

Removed a sanity check in the code that raised an exception if the clone depth of a volume to be cloned exceeded the rbd_max_clone_depth config value.  A consequence of this check was that if an operator lowered the value, volumes whose clone depth was greater than the new value (as would be allowed by the previous, higher setting) could no longer be cloned.

cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py.message: This isn't part of your change, but might as well fix it while you're working on this.  I suggest just deleting the highlighted sentence.  (The help text for the option on lines 77-79 already explains what a zero value means.)
removing this doesn't seem like a good idea, see my comment on PS10 L#729

I have two problems with this code:
(1) it's not correct; see https://review.opendev.org/#/c/759536/
(2) it violates the single responsibility principle for a function that's supposed to determine the clone depth
I suppose you could add 'Note that lowering this value does not affect existing volumes whose clone depth exceeds the new value.', or do you think that would be more confusing than saying nothing?

this code doesn't account for flattening a chain of volumes.
Suppose we have a value of rbd_max_clone_depth = 5 and we've 5 volumes created (initial volume and 4 in it's clone chain)
we now change the rbd_max_clone_depth=1 then this will only flatten the latest volume created and not the previous ones in chain
We need a mechanism to flatten all volumes in the chain

OK, just wanted to verify.  It might be worth pointing this out in the release note (or maybe the option help text?) so it's clear what the expected behavior is, namely, that we don't go back and change all the current volumes.

Quick question: is there a technical Ceph problem if we flatten volume #6 but leave volumes 2 through 5 unflattened?  Or is your point that there are now volumes in the system that "violate" the max_clone_depth?
My concern is the 2nd part, clone volume chains existing in the system exceeding the max_clone_depth value but that maybe just my opinion.

This is the wording we use in nova CLI but in OSC we generally say something like what you have in the docs, i.e. "Only available starting with ``--os-compute-api-version 2.10``."
I don't see negative tests for any of these commands to specify --user-id with a version less than 2.10.
nit: maybe it'd be good to pull this into a module-level helper method called _validate_user_id or something? Just to avoid the copy/paste.
I don't see a test for the keypair show command with --user-id.

releasenotes/notes/keypair-user-id-db694.message: nit: you could remove this, it's redundant

tests/fixtures/config/split-config/git/c.message: Is this new content necessary? we seem to be creating a conflict between job definitions not project pipelines.
Yes this is needed because common-config runs no jobs in check so zuul doesn't report at all to the pr in the test case without this (due to the test pr introducing a config error).
Actually when thinking about I think probably not, I'll try this out tomorrow.

zuul/configloader.py.message:
I know you just copied it, but since it's making it to the user I think we should explicitly say what's going on.  I would suggest

"Configuration in %s ignored because project-branch is already configured" % (fn)

or something like that

manila_tempest_tests/tests/scenario/mana.message: Can this be set after the following line?  Unless I'm missing something, it's only used at line 415, inside the scope of the 'if' at line 402.
Actually, it was supposed to be used in other places.
suggest using "access_rule" to clarify the meaning further, and separate concerns with the other access rule data in the signature: access_level and access_to
Add - this is not required if "access_rule" is set.
access_to: client to provide access to; this is not required if "access_rule" is set.

cmd/baremetal/showhosts.go.message: please keep any logic like this in pkg module.

This is a lot like the other functions in the cmd tree (in fact it was copied almost verbatim from the eject media), should a pkg/baremetal package be created to house this if none of the other functions in the cmd/baremetal package doesn't share the same format?

This is the only place where the 3rd argument to GetHostSelections is meaningful. I think it'd be cleaner if we simply bypassed that function here

  selectors := []remote.HostSelector{remote.ByKind(document.BareMetalHostKind)}

manifests/site/openstack-test-site/phase.message: What does this group correspond to? I noticed some additional phases in this change that are not in this list.

This corresponds to the three main phases for capo namely
 - clusterctl-init-ephemeral (for initializing the mgmt. cluster)
 - controlplane-target (for deploying controlplane of the target cluster)
 - workers-target (for deploying worker nodes of the target cluster)

I'd take a look at the additional phases such as clusterctl-init-target, clusterctl-move and either add/refer from the manifests/phases.

whitebox_tempest_plugin/api/compute/test.message:
Ah, good point. I guess I'll abandon this for now, it's not the most important thing. I just wanted to have it documented somewhere why they were being blacklisted.

So wait, if focal has libvirt 6.0.0, we could propose a patch to project-config to use that with the nested-virt flavor, and then we could unskip these upstream?

yes we can. we just need to create new labels that use the nested flavor but focal images.

focal was not supported fully in devstack when we blacklisted the tests so we went that route instead of adding the new labels but i dont see any reason not to do that now that focal is supported

also the way we are doing it currently is better
this will disable it for everyone
the other way disabled it just for the ci env upstream
downstream we already have the correct libvirt and the tests are running.

zuul-tests.d/container-roles-jobs.yaml.message:
I'm on the fence about this -- it only works if you update kernel settings to reset to cgroups v1 and then reboot, and then also do manual configuration to firewalld [1].  Without doing all this docker doesn't work, so the package install is pretty pointless.  While you can reboot nodes in opendev infra, you drop the console and it's generally a pain (i have some unfinished examples with kernel-updating roles for kafs sitting around somehwere...)

I probably should have put in a blacklist abort: with I025613bee8c0a8513afa90331431d2c18b616464 although it would have implicitly failed with no packages.  However, now there are packages, I think we want to abort and tell people that what they think they are installing won't actually work (I can't imagine anyone is actually interested in making it work in this role).

CentOS 8 apparently needs firewalld rules setup too; it's probably broken by default too [2].  Though I guess that stays just because it was at least installing before.

A todo list item would be to update the test to start a container and make sure it can access the internet.  

[1] https://github.com/docker/for-linux/issues/955#issuecomment-694825085
[2] https://github.com/docker/for-linux/issues/873#issuecomment-694984685
Oh good point, then should the role fails if cgroupv2 is enabled?

This could be directly in list_skipped_deployment without need two tasks for it:

  list_skipped_deployment: "{{ (tempest_cloud_name in ['undercloud']) | ternary('undercloud', 'overcloud') }}"
why do we need ternary, why not just use {{ tempest_cloud_name }} directly?
i see thanks so 'standalone' breaks it and we can't just assign the value of tempest_cloud_name directly

tempest_cloud_name -> deployment type
standalone - overcloud
overcloud - overcloud
undercloud - undercloud

That's why we used ternary operator.
i don't see a condition here about 'only undercloud'?

In this same playbook we have a task to create clouds.yaml to queens, rocky and stein. If this is something specific for featureset003, you can set the tempest_cloud_name in the featureset itself.
